top_categories.workout_context: Fairfield Harvest Rush's Iowa rolling gravel rewards steady threshold power. Surging and recovering costs more watts than just holding.
Fairfield Harvest Rush's Iowa rolling, Local event forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 55 miles.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Fairfield Harvest Rush. Train it until it feels boring.
At Fairfield Harvest Rush, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Fairfield Harvest Rush's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before October.
When someone attacks on Iowa rolling gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Fairfield Harvest Rush, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
55 miles on Iowa rolling gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Varied gradients on Iowa rolling gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
2-minute all-out efforts on Iowa rolling gravel. Closing gaps, responding to attacks, sprinting for position. Train the burn.
Smooth pedaling at 55 miles saves muscle. Bad technique at mile 10 is invisible. At mile 80 it's a cramp.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Fairfield Harvest Rush’s 55 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Fairfield Harvest Rush requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on iowa rolling gravel to build confidence. Expect: iowa rolling, local event, midwest gravel.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and G Spot to prepare you for 55 miles of iowa rolling gravel in Fairfield, Iowa.
